Award.AwardTitle: Ongoing Development of a Human Population Genetics Resource with Forensic Application

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The current use of DNA in criminal forensics, in identification of individuals in mass disasters, and in connecting individuals to their biological families (e.g., childhood abductees) is already well established with good scientific justification. Advanced molecular technology, however, is likely to make new types of genetic markers even better at these tasks and provide useful forensic evidence not possible with the techniques currently used in standard forensic applications. Previous to such new implementation, the scientific basis for the new markers and their interpretations must be developed. And because the United States has such a large proportion of its citizens with ancestries from all parts of the world, the science must have a global perspective.

The core aspects of this research project involve identifying data in the literature (and public databases) that are potentially relevant to understanding human genetic variation broadly, especially as relevant to forensic use of DNA variation. The most relevant data from these widely dispersed sources will then be assembled and evaluated. The extant large database, ALFRED (ALlele FREquency Database), currently inclusive of 37 million allele frequency entries, will be enriched with the new data, while the web-based interfaces to these data will be modified, in conjunction with the forensic community, to make the data readily available for research and useful in actual forensic practice. The research will provide additional scientific support for existing forensic use of DNA, and will provide the necessary scientific support of use of new scientific methodologies in the likely expansion of forensic application of DNA.

The project involves computerization of existing and newly available data, a significant task involving skills in bioinformatics and an understanding of the necessary documentation. The ALFRED database and the web interface were originally designed to allow the integrated documentation of the molecular, population, and publication aspects of each datum; those functions have worked well for several years and will be adequate for assembling the data in the current project. FROG-kb (Forensic Resource/Reference on Genetics knowledge base), which allows several specific forensic views of the data and actual calculation of relevant statistics, will be enhanced through the project. And as the interface currently exists only in a prototype version, a major aspect of the research will focus on improving functionality based on the accumulated data and analyses of those data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to facilitate access to and promote the proper use of data based
on well documented empirical studies of human genetic variation with an emphasis for
applications in a forensic setting.  Specifically, the project expanded the content
and improved the functionality as well as the user friendliness of an electronic
database known by the short acronym: FROG-kb. The longer name is: Forensic
Resource/Reference of Genetics knowledge base. FROG-kb has been under
development for several years as an educational tool to assist forensic teaching
and research and to facilitate the practice of forensic work. Anthropologists,
archaeologists, and medical researchers can also benefit from this resource
since they deal with similar issues at times in their investigations.  FROG-kb
is freely accessible on the worldwide web at https://frog.med.yale.edu/FrogKB/.
The project was jointly funded by the National Science Foundation and by the
National Institute of Justice which is part of the U.S. Department of Justice.

FROG-kb is an electronic interface that builds upon and has access to a large human
genetics database called ALFRED (https://alfred.med.yale.edu/alfred/).  ALFRED is
an ALlele FREquency Database that contains information on the frequencies of alleles
of human DNA markers sampled from human populations from around the world. The curated
ALFRED database includes detailed molecular definitions of the DNA markers, the number
of individuals sampled from each ethnic group studied, descriptions of the populations
and the particular samples studied from those populations as well as citations to the
published scientific literature reporting the allele frequency information. An important
goal of the project was to continue expanding the contents of ALFRED with DNA marker
information (especially with SNPs--single nucleotide polymorphisms) useful to human
forensics and anthropological studies. During the funding period the number of
frequency tables in ALFRED increased from about 37 million to about 40.3 million.

An important objective for ALFRED and FROG-kb is to expand the frequency data
available for SNPs studied in many different human populations in order to make it
possible to evaluate their usefulness in identifying individuals, assessing ancestral
origins, and differentiating among closely related individuals within families. New
data comes from the published scientific literature and from collaborating research
laboratories around the world. It is especially valuable for applied work in forensics
and anthropology to have frequency data for the same SNPs on as many reference
populations as possible. This makes it possible to have more meaningful and accurate
interpretations of calculations that can be carried out in FROG-kb. To be efficient
forensic researchers develop panels containing a relatively small number (dozens)
of SNPs customized for specialized purposes such as identifying individuals who die
in airplane crashes, linking material evidence to perpetrators in criminal investigations,
and exonerating individuals innocent of crimes for which they are prosecuted.

During the project the FROG-kb interface was modified extensively and online documentation
was expanded. The FROG-kb and ALFRED interfaces have new functionalities designed to be
more intuitive and easier to use. Users can input data to obtain the results of calculations
from fourteen SNP panels published by researchers to help with investigations dealing with
human identification (3 panels), ancestry inference (10 panels), and predicting eye
color (1 panel).  The extensive documentation in FROG-kb includes an FAQ section, a
21 page user manual, expanded examples showing how to organize and input information
to generate results for specialized calculations, a diagrammatic pipeline illustrating
data entry into different kinds of SNP panels, and links to other related Resources and
educational materials on the web.  Both FROG-kb and ALFRED now have ‘Announcement’ pages
highlighting recent additions and changes. ‘Contact us’ and ‘Feedback’ functions were also
built in to help process queries and suggestions from the users. A collaboration with the
Forensic Technology Center of Excellence (FTCoE) section of Research Triangle Institute
International (RTI) helped in publicizing FROG-kb and in making the new interface easier
for users to interact with. Near the end of the project’s funding period FROG-kb averaged
a little over 300 users/visitors per month with internet addresses from government,
educational, and commercial organizations. Most of these users were located in the
United States and Canada but there were also visitors from Japan, Russia, France,
China, Italy, India and other countries.

FROG-kb’s forensic focus along with the extensive SNP data provided by ALFRED
facilitates the understanding of and use of SNPs in forensic applications. SNPs
represent a relatively new tool for forensic workers with special advantages in
many investigations. The educational aspects of FROG-kb will help forensic technicians
understand and employ SNPs when match probability and ancestral origin calculations are
accepted by judicial courts in the future. Once they are accepted in judicial proceedings,
the calculations generated by FROG-kb in printed reports (that can already be
generated) could be submitted as evidence.
